content: Qualitative research conducted, analyzed, and summarized by AI.

title: Product-Led AI (9 minute read)
content: In an age where foundation models make it possible for anyone to build an AI company, what makes for a defensible business? Instead of using AI to enhance a product, the technology should be the key unlock to drive a company’s entire product development and business strategy. This article outlines how AI-first products can reinvent networks and marketplaces, create entirely new startup categories, and establish AI co-pilots for knowledge workers.

title: A State Of The Union For Early Stage Venture (10 minute read)
content: The new technological epoch of AI and mixed reality makes this a seminal time for startup creation.

title: Respect And Admiration (4 minute read)
content: We all get caught up in chasing money and status, but don’t forget to chase respect and admiration as well.

title: Q2 E-Commerce Review (8 minute read)
content: The e-commerce industry put in a strong Q2, which looks set to continue in Q3, even with the fresh competition for consumer spending from travel and entertainment.

title: Whispers Of The Future (3 minute read)
content: LLMs are amazing, but they require immense amounts of hardware. For this reason, the software will evolve to have a hardware architecture where some of the model is processed on the computer and some in the cloud.

title: Big Tech Isn’t Shelling Out For Acquisitions Like It Used To (2 minute read)
content: There were only 18 acquisitions by Big Tech in Q2, an 18-quarter low.

title: The Impact of Gen AI on Enterprise SaaS Today (30 minute podcast)
content: A deep dive into the impacts of Gen AI on enterprise SaaS today. It looks at the impact on both new Gen AI startups and existing ones.

title: Types of Independent Board Members for Startups (3 minute read)
content: Quick and helpful recap on the types of independent board members to be thinking about when considering growing your board. You always have to be thinking about board dynamics. Never make a snap decision on bringing an independent member on.

title: Dear SaaStr: How Do You Respond to a VC Who Says They Don’t Invest in Your Space? (1 minute read)
content: We hear this time and again from founders who seem to take it personally or wonder if they should try and convince the VC of their value. Pro tip: Don’t. Just move on.

title: Bool Video (Product)
content: Create top-notch videos to skyrocket your sales.

title: M1 Project (Product)
content: Research your ideal customer up to 80% faster.

title: Algomo (Product)
content: Build custom ChatGPT-like chatbots for your website instantly.

title: A reflection on a decade: 10 lessons after 10 years of VC (3 minute read)
content: While we focus on founders here, it is helpful to see how VCs think, especially over the long haul.

title: All You Need To Become A Servant Leader (5 minute read)
content: Exceptional leadership could be the difference between success and failure for your startup. Servant leadership, a leadership style that empowers employees based on the premise that if employees are satisfied and cared for, they will be more motivated to give their best, could be the leadership style your startup needs.

title: Examining Andreessen Horowitz’s Record (8 minute read)
content: This article examines a16z’s method for evaluating startups both in the boom times where they did very well and the current bust times where they aren’t doing as well.

title: Square’s outage (1 minute read)
content: Payments company Square had an outage on Thursday last week. This happens of course, but the impact on businesses that use Square to take payments can be huge. The event added fuel to the ongoing culture war around migrating to a cashless society.

title: Confidence vs Arrogance (4 minute read)
content: As a founder, you have to be confident in what you’re doing. That’s how you sell people on the vision to invest in you, work with you, buy from you. However, you need to understand the boundary between confidence and arrogance.

title: Regulating artificial intelligence (17 minute read)
content: Slowing the pace of innovation allows competitor countries to catch up. Letting innovation run unfettered can unlock a Pandora's Box of problems. This article spins an interesting story that showcases why regulating artificial intelligence is so difficult.

title: Integration strategy (7 minute read)
content: As you scale, the number of integrations you have with providers is going to increase. Your CRM, Finance stack, ERP, and collaboration tools all need to talk to each other. Interoperability between applications is a continuous strategic decision for founders. You need to have an owner of this strategy in your startup.

title: When to borrow debt (2 minute read)
content: Selling equity in your startup is the most expensive form of financing. Debt is cheaper, but only accessible under certain circumstances, like when you know your unit economics, have product market fit, and have proven repeatable channels to find customers.

title: The top 10 mistakes founders make after $10m ARR (9 minute read)
content: From stepping away from founder-led sales completely to hiring mistakes. Here’s a list of some things you can be mindful of as a founder of a scaling startup that’s in the growth phase.

title: Trickle (Product)
content: Trickle produces AI-generated insightful summaries for each uploaded screenshot.

title: Buildshare (Product)
content: Generate product updates for Twitter when you ship new code.

title: AI Score My Site (Product)
content: Find out if your website can be discovered and ranked by AI-powered search engines and what you can do to improve it.

title: If you want to trick investors, tell them your CAAR (5 minute read)
content: Annual Recurring Revenue (ARR) is a staple metric of investor expectations. Contracted Annual Recurring Revenue (CAAR) is being used more by founders to show unrealized revenue from committed contracts. It bumps the numbers, but it might leave you in hot water further down the line.

title: How AI can spark both technological and business model innovation (2 minute read)
content: Truly great innovation comes in pairs. Technology innovation and business model innovation. They work together and deliver outlier results. AI is the next technology innovation, but have we found its counterpart on the business model side yet?

title: Securing AI is the Next Big Platform Opportunity (4 minute read)
content: When it comes to AI and security, there is a significant amount of work and effort required. This article breaks down the risks and challenges and looks at the opportunities for companies in this new world order.

title: Swan’s $40m raise (2 minute read)
content: Despite global fintech funding being down 84% YoY, French fintech Swan bags $40m to scale their embedded banking services across Europe. Hope for fintech and Europe?

title: FTX gets approval to sell its crypto assets (2 minute read)
content: FTX has been given approval to liquidate its assets in order to begin paying back its users in USD. However, it still has a lot of assets. How will this liquidation impact the crypto market as supply floods the market?

title: Xbox introduces Embedded Finance in Gaming (2 minute read)
content: Xbox has launched the Xbox Mastercard in collaboration with Barclays. The Xbox Mastercard is a rewards card that players can use to earn points through everyday purchases to redeem on games. Wasn’t it Angela Stange who said in 2019 that every company will be a fintech company?

title: Signs your Chief People Officer isn’t scaling (3 minute read)
content: If you have a Chief People Officer who is overly focused on the transactional parts of their operations, like payroll and benefits, doesn’t speak up in executive team meetings, and has morale or turnover issues in their own team, you’ve got big problems.

title: How I CEO: On Taking Advice As A Leader (4 minute read)
content: Leadership is challenging, but getting advice from experienced peers and investors makes the job much easier. The key to getting the most out of advice is considering the situational context around the advice and maintaining enough humility to properly receive the advice.

title: Picking Sharp Problems, Increasing Virality, And Unique Product Frameworks (76 minute audio)
content: A discussion on why you need to find the “sharpest” problems, how to operationalize continuous customer discovery, tactical strategies for making your products more viral, and more.

title: TimeOS (Product)
content: Your personalized AI for meeting notes and scheduling.

title: Solidroad (Product)
content: A flight simulator for Sales conversations. Empower your reps to practice at their own pace, refine their approach, and receive tailored feedback.

title: ChartGenAI (Product)
content: Generate any chart you want using a single sentence.

title: In conversation with Sam Altman (24 minute video)
content: Azeem from Exponential View sits down with Sam Altman during his latest world tour to talk about AI, regulation, and his thoughts on the future of OpenAI.

title: Reverse engineering your ideal life (3 minute read)
content: As founders, we can often get lost in the to-do’s. The details of these tasks consume us. Here’s a nice reminder to reflect on the real goals of life, which often don’t involve money. It’s about the people you retain and live with along the way.

title: The importance of founder pedigree in emerging technologies (7 minute read)
content: This is a fascinating read that argues how investors behave around new technologies. Without benchmarks and historical insight, investors will revert back to founder-market-fit, using signals like pedigree and education. A canonical example of this is the amount of researchers and PhD wielders that have been recipients of the latest AI funding boom.

title: Three in four Americans believe AI will reduce jobs (3 minute read)
content: Most Americans think artificial intelligence will negatively affect the U.S. job market, with 75% saying it will decrease the total number of jobs over the next 10 years.

title: Bosses are back in charge (5 minute read)
content: Between RTO, AI, and all the layoffs in tech, it feels like power in the workplace has shifted away from the employees and back to employers.

title: SoftBank makes a billion-dollar bet on autonomous trucking startup (2 minute read)
content: This is a big shift for SoftBank, who in recent years has been moving towards doing smaller and more selective deals.

title: How to take time off and use it well (11 minute read)
content: Jumping directly into a new job or a startup idea straight after another is a bit like dating immediately after a breakup. You don’t want to fall into the “rebound” idea or job. Taking time off requires planning your finances and setting self-expectations.

title: How to be a better sales executive (2 minute read)
content: Whether you’re a founder doing sales or a sales rep, it seems we’ve collectively gotten a little bit slower at promptly responding to customers, follow-ups, and inbound interest. The best way to keep someone engaged is to not keep them waiting.

title: 5 interesting learnings from Samsara at almost $1bn ARR (2 minute read)
content: Growing 40% YoY between 2022 and 2023 and cash flow positive, Samsara is back to growth. There are several stats in this article, but perhaps the standout is how Samsara compensated its sales team on net new revenue, rather than new logos, allowing them to upsell into their existing user base or seek out new business.

title: Kick (Product)
content: Kick provides daily bookkeeping for the modern business owner.

title: OneAudio (Product)
content: Transform voice recordings into clean summarized notes.

title: FeatureCat (Product)
content: Collect more feedback, plan the right features, and build better products.

title: Is fintech a house of cards? (9 minute read)
content: The rosy macroeconomic conditions of the 2010s have certainly come to an end. The relationship between fixed interchange fees, which often form the staple of fintech revenue, and unfixed increasing interest rates is putting pressure on newly minted technology companies.

title: Why venture capitalists will overpay for seed rounds (3 minute read)
content: The startup ecosystem has experienced a tumultuous period, with the transition from a hyper-growth market to one that rewards a different style of operation. While overall valuations in the seed stage have remained relatively unchanged, the top decile of startups has been less impacted than the second decile, largely due to the involvement of better-known firms who are happy to pay more for a spot on the cap table.

title: How to Become an Angel Investor (7 minute read)
content: Most people think that angel investing is for the ultra-wealthy. As it turns out, the vast majority of angels are investing $1k-$5k into startups. This in-depth post provides tactical tips for how to get started.

title: Instacart prices shares at $30 as IPO market warms up (1 minute read)
content: Instacart plans to sell 8% of its stock, which could bring in around $660 million, in order to fuel demand for online grocery shopping post-pandemic.

title: Santander commits to €100 million fund for Spanish startups (1 minute read)
content: Santander committed €67m to a new €100m fund in an effort to help boost Spain’s entrepreneurship ecosystem. It’s always cool seeing large global banks invest in their roots.

title: My Reflections on my summer in India’s Silicon Valley (7 minute read)
content: In this article, Ashu Garg, General Partner at Foundational Capital, compares Bangalore’s emerging SaaS scene to Silicon Valley, predicting that by 2030, the enterprise software industry will revolve around two poles—Silicon Valley and Bangalore.

title: Can we even afford to do SMB sales in the U.S. anymore? (3 minute read)
content: Inflation up, salaries up, marketing costs up, CAC on the rise. In response to higher expected OTE from sales reps, some startups are moving their SMB sales teams outside of the US.

title: Subscription vs Usage Based pricing models (8 minute read)
content: A fascinating read that breaks down the pros and cons of usage-based versus subscription pricing. More founders are leaning into usage-based pricing as a way to better align their revenue with the value a user extracts from their product.

title: How SaaS business models are changing (5 minute read)
content: The market is tough right now and it's impacting how founders grow their SaaS startups. We’re seeing product-led growth tactics surge, headcount-based growth being less rewarded, pricing changes being used as a strategic lever, and increased focus on reducing cloud costs.

title: CX Assist (Product)
content: Personalized, AI-powered email responses to boost efficiency, nurture clients, and transform your sales and support customer experience.

title: DialMe (Product)
content: A voice-enabled AI interviewer built to get users talking and you learning.

title: Klu AI (Product)
content: Unify your data so that you can seamlessly search and discover across apps and files.

title: Fighting against regulatory capture for a better future (16 minute read)
content: Regulation tends to slow things down and make innovation more expensive. To overcome regulatory barriers, startups need to be both well-resourced and well organized. Regulations are a set of rules and you need to know them in order to play the game. Now is the time for innovation hubs like Silicon Valley to get closer to and work with Washington DC.

title: A Golden Age Of Building? (29 minute read)
content: An informative read of lessons from people achieving great things quickly, for example, the Empire State Building, the Pentagon, Skunk Works, and SpaceX.

title: AI Regulation from Elad Gil (13 minute read)
content: This article unpacks the challenges with regulation, including how it can stifle innovation, slow progress, and ultimately drive these innovators to build their technology in alternative countries where restrictions may not be as…strict.

title: Musk, Gates, and Zuckerberg walk into an AI meeting (1 minute read)
content: Sounds like the start of a bad joke. Tech titans Elon Musk, Bill Gates, and Mark Zuckerberg met in Washington on Wednesday to talk about AI regulation. They were joined by founders from leading AI companies like Anthropic and OpenAI. Hopefully, we hear some insight from the meeting soon!

title: Software transcends borders—why not money? (5 minute read)
content: Global money movement is a really complex topic. It’s really a lot like language. Each country grew up with its own system and way of communicating with money, and we’re still in the phase of translating that into a global language.

title: The wild west of e-commerce (10 minute read)
content: In light of Klaviyo’s S-1 filing, this article dives into the e-commerce space and the infrastructure that runs it. Much of the plumbing behind e-commerce is invisible to the consumer. Amazon’s FBA, Klaviyo’s marketing, Shopify storefronts, and wholesale marketplaces like Faire all enable the gears of e-commerce to turn without the consumer knowing about it.

title: How to measure what marketing activities are actually driving revenue (17 minute read)
content: A comprehensive read covering how to map your funnel, set up tooling, and start tracking the right data from marketing activities at your B2B startup.

title: Airbnb CEO Brian Chesky on why he's deep in the product details (60 minute podcast)
content: The bigger the company gets, the more likely it is that the founder or CEO doesn’t spend time with their customers. Brian Chesky has a refreshing take on how a CEO should always maintain a high degree of customer-centricity and product knowledge.

title: Helpful boards (8 minute read)
content: Board meetings can often be a huge waste of time. A board member should be your confidant. They should tell hard truths and play the long game. Here’s a helpful breakdown of the signals that indicate whether you’ve got a good board or not.

title: Capsule (Product)
content: The AI-powered video editor for content and marketing teams.

title: Cardinal (Product)
content: An AI-powered backlog enriching your features with customer feedback and revenue data.

title: Shortwave (Product)
content: The AI executive assistant you’ve been looking for.

title: How to avoid doing fraud (4 minute read)
content: The most important rule of business is to never lie about your metrics. False metrics quickly spiral out of control, and you’ll begin to layer on fraud after fraud to keep the lie alive. Before you know it, the only thing that exists is the lie you’ve told and not the company behind it.

title: Generative AI’s Act Two (15 minute read)
content: Generative AI’s first act of developing foundational models and novelty apps is coming to an end. In its place comes Act Two: where generative AI solves human problems end-to-end.

title: Failing better (4 minute read)
content: Startups fail all the time, but not all of them fail gracefully. The core things to think about if you need to close shop include your team, your accounts payable, and your customers. Make sure you preserve the relationship with your team, don’t screw small businesses you owe money to, and don’t kick customers who may rely on your product or service to the curb.

title: HSBC makes $1bn available for climate tech companies (1 minute read)
content: Last week we flagged that Santandar was committing £100m to Spanish startups, now HSBC is weighing in on climate. It's looking to support climate companies that are focusing on EV charging, battery storage, sustainable food and agriculture, and carbon removal technologies.

title: The rise of offline apps (3 minute read)
content: Sales of “dumb phones” are on the rise, the count of apps in Apple’s App Store and Google’s Play Store are down 25%. As the appetite for tangible experiences grows, companies are popping up that help facilitate IRL interactions in order to get people away from their phones.

title: Dual Threat CEOs that Build and Invest (2 minute read)
content: While a tad bit controversial, being a dual-threat CEO can be really handy. Understanding deals, talking with entrepreneurs, and seeing what is happening through deal flow is actually really beneficial for a CEO who is usually too in the mix of their own company.

title: Communicating upwards in your organization (10 minute read)
content: “Don’t bring me problems, bring me solutions”. We all know it, but rarely do you hear it being said in an organization. Effective communication with your leadership is about acknowledging they have limited cognitive bandwidth and acting accordingly. If you’re at the top, this is a nice reminder to have empathy over what’s happening below.

title: Things to keep in mind when preparing a product launch (4 minute read)
content: Time spent on UX tinkering should be proportional to the level of conviction you have on your hypothesis. Have a launch checklist and allocate an overall owner for each one. Be patient - launches often take longer than forecast.

title: The worst outcome is a mediocre success (4 minute read)
content: If you test a hypothesis and it fails, good, you can now try something new. If it only kinda works, you’re in this limbo state of deciding whether to double down and re-test or pull the plug. This is where time and resources go to die. Defining success and failure specifically and leaving little room for the inbetween is vital.

title: Docera (Product)
content: An AI-powered tool that simplifies document creation for personal and professional use.

title: BulkCorrector (Product)
content: Never deal with ChatGPT’s character limit again - BulkCorrector segments your text into manageable pieces for bulk corrections.

title: Journalist Hunt (Product)
content: A database of more than 340,000 journalists to feature your business.

title: How to drive word of mouth (1+ hour podcast)
content: Goodwill, NPS, mindshare - we often used these words to explain the ambient value created in the ecosystem when people simply love our product. But can you really architect and measure the value of word of mouth? The CPO of Wise thinks so.

title: When it’s over: thoughts on selling your company (4 minute read)
content: Going through an exit, whether positive or negative, is an emotional experience. You’re selling something you’ve likely poured years into, and it’ll never be the same again. Deciding when, and for how much, often comes down to trusting your gut.

title: Vertical operating systems and embedded fintech (8 minute read)
content: We’re witnessing the convergence of SaaS and embedded finance. SaaS platforms are introducing financial services into their existing offerings, increasing their user LTV through stickiness, and unlocking new revenue streams.

title: Investment in battery startups on the rise (3 minute read)
content: In the last month, we’ve witnessed three $1bn+ investments into battery startups. The space is on trend to surpass 2021 funding levels by the end of the year, which is perhaps the only industry out there to do so.

title: Series, which aims to replace ERP systems, lands $25M (9 minute read)
content: Series is a platform designed to centralize and automate business finance and operations. Backed by $25M in funding, it offers modular ERP-like features, enabling companies to choose functionalities best suited for them. By streamlining operations, it aims to reduce the complexity and cost businesses face when managing multiple vendors and systems.

title: How Is AI Going to Impact The SaaS Landscape Over The Coming Years with a16z GP Kristina Shen (7 minute read)
content: We all know SaaS is going to be impacted by AI, but the question is what is the next wave going to look like? This in-depth discussion with Kristina Shen goes into why it’s more about insights than information and unlocking the real power of AI for SaaS.

title: How Miro grows: tactical lessons from the $17.5B whiteboard (40 minute read)
content: This is a long but rewarding read that unpacks the nuances of product-led growth, freemium offerings, the differences between onboarding users with single-player and multiplayer products, and how to intelligently think about product-led sales. It’s one for your weekend coffee.

title: Experience Doesn’t Matter (6 minute read)
content: While we might not completely agree, experience can sometimes be overrated when it comes to hires. This article goes into the weeds on why it's more than just experience when it comes to looking at candidates as well as some tactics for focusing on the fundamentals that a potential candidate might have.

title: The biggest difference between running a 10 person startup versus 100 (2 minute read)
content: As a founder, you have to let go. Focus your efforts on hiring great VPs and give them the freedom to make decisions and ultimately their own mistakes. But only let go once you know you have that great VP in place.

title: Product planning brainstorm template (Figma Template)
content: A template you can use to brainstorm your product roadmap with your team.

title: Vespio (Product)
content: Vespio provides AI-powered sentiment analysis so your sales teams never waste leads.

title: Bestever (Product)
content: Create brilliant marketing visuals in minutes using AI.

title: Thoughts on early-stage partnerships (5 minute read)
content: Partnering with bigger firms for your startup can often seem like a silver bullet to your distribution worries. In reality, there’s absolutely zero substitute for developing your own audience. Lots of big partnerships are just efforts to gather information.

title: How To Use AI to Brainstorm A Billion-Dollar Business Idea (3 minute read)
content: Guest author Dan Kraemer for Crunchbase News goes into his methodology around leveraging AI to brainstorm the next big idea.

title: The generalist disease (5 minute read)
content: The hallmark symptom of people with Generalist Disease is optimizing for optionality. Individuals who pursue good brands to build their resumes, jumping from each every few years and diving into something completely new each time. This is an excellent strategy early in your career - to figure out what you enjoy - but later on, you need to specialize in something.

title: What to watch in India (25 minute read)
content: India has a population of 1.4 billion. By 2041, 59% of the population will be of working age. That’s a huge workforce. The government has been investing in tech, and large VCs are propping up in the region. This deep-dive on eight startups showcases the innovation coming from the Indian ecosystem.

title: AI, Hardware, and Virtual Reality (11 minute read)
content: AI, combined with hardware, is going to enable groundbreaking forms of virtual and augmented reality. Here’s a breakdown of the latest news in each of those domains.

title: Is Data Still A Moat? (2 minute read)
content: Generative AI is reshaping the traditional value placed on vast data collections. The uniqueness and importance of proprietary data may be waning as large language models can be fine-tuned with minimal data and even generate synthetic datasets.

title: Is your international growth strategy a hot mess? (5 minute read)
content: The prospects of internationalization at your startup are exciting. Bigger TAM, new revenue, risk diversification - but often there’s a misalignment between internal buzz and external traction that’s explained by a lack of preparation. International expansion is a strategy, not a quick tactic.

title: How founders can engage with a Chief People Officer (4 minute read)
content: Regardless of the seniority of the Chief People Officer, have them report to you. This signals that the founder/CEO cares intimately about the needs of employees and keeps you connected to the culture and general vibe.

title: 8 Ways SaaS Companies Can Use AI To Get Ahead (12 minute read)
content: This blog post features several AI SaaS use cases for various departments, highlighting ways the technology can be used to gain a competitive edge.

title: Strut (Product)
content: Strut is an AI notebook that turns rough notes into finished content.

title: Collato (Product)
content: AI assistant for product teams to find, summarize, and generate new content based on your own product knowledge.

title: App Store Spy (Product)
content: Gain immediate insights into apps, niches, and keywords.

title: Working at a Startup vs in Big Tech (11 minute read)
content: Startups are an excellent environment to learn and build generalist skill sets, but they’re financially risky and stressful. Big Tech enables you to build a specialism and a financial buffer, but you’ll have to deal with bureaucracy and a lack of purpose. Written from an engineer's perspective.

title: Inside mind reading AI (24 minute watch)
content: More startups are popping up to help us read and manipulate our mental states to help us relax, learn, and reduce pain. Neuralink, Mendi, and FocusCalm are just some of these startups. These companies will gather data from users if they are given access to their brains. Who owns this data?

title: What are the biggest problems you face as a startup founder? (3 minute read)
content: Your biggest challenge evolves as the company grows, from finding a co-founder to simply sticking to it and launching new products in order to expand your TAM.

title: How companies spy on their employees (3 minute read)
content: Monitoring employees' activity goes beyond just checking who swiped their badge to get into the office. Tools are propping up that enable employers to monitor employee internet usage and even take screen recordings.

title: Fintech loses UK funding crown (2 minute read)
content: The UK’s energy startup sector has raised the most VC cash in 2023, knocking fintech off the top spot it has held for a decade. It has raised $3bn so far this year versus fintech’s $2.1bn, down from a high of $13.5bn in 2021.

title: AI and jobs (1 minute read)
content: AI is great at doing tasks, but not so much doing full jobs. Sam Altman argues that AI will enable humans to focus on different work that AI can’t do.

title: Life visions and why you probably need one (3 minute read)
content: You likely have OKRs for your business, but do you have them for yourself? We often just wake up each day and try our best. Having an idea of what you’re working towards specifically can help make it feel less like Groundhog Day.

title: What Sets Great Teams Apart (90 minute video)
content: A conversation on what exactly takes a team from simply a good team to a truly great team.

title: What We Learned About Paid Ads For A Dev Tool (7 minute read)
content: A deep dive into how to make your paid ads more effective, especially if your target customers are developers.

title: Krea Logo Illusions (Product)
content: Turn your logos into amazing visual illusions.

title: Semiform (Product)
content: Replace your forms with AI agents in order to get higher response rates and happier users.

title: Colors AI (Product)
content: Automatically gather, consolidate, and categorize customer feedback to prioritize product development.

title: The business of annual letters (6 minute read)
content: A big part of a CEO's job is to communicate with their investors. Good writing often reflects good thinking. Some of the most successful companies and investors out there are also great writers that publish a yearly letter to their investors.

title: Company Culture is a Crucial Factor for Job Seekers (5 minute read)
content: Written for operators, but useful for founders if you flip it. Your culture should be identifiable throughout your hiring process. Give time for potential hires to interview you and learn about your company culture.

title: Rules for better thinking, how to reduce blindspots, & more (2 hour video)
content: Two podcasting legends, Shane Parrish and Tim Ferris, combine forces to talk about tools, tactics, and mental models for clearer thinking.

title: Emerging trends and shifts in the Indian fintech landscape (2 minute read)
content: We flagged the Indian software scene in the last edition, here’s a quick dive into the Indian fintech space, which saw $442m in funding in Q2 2023.

title: The Mobile Revolution vs. The AI Revolution (12 minute read)
content: AI is a technological revolution more akin to the invention of the internet than the proliferation of smartphones, as computers will no longer act like calculators but as something like the human brain.

title: Small Applications, Growing Protocols (8 minute read)
content: This essay describes the big potential of small apps. It goes over the challenges they face in building defensible, long-term businesses as well as a possible solution by building on top of growing protocols.

title: A deep dive on the monthly to annual plan pricing trick (6 minute read)
content: A simple trick: if your average user stays around for four months, price your annual plan at five months. This allows you to increase your LTV by 25%, and it’s a really simple change to make.

title: Talking expansion with Public.com GM International, Dann Bibas (6 minute read)
content: Internationalizing, whether launching totally into new markets or bringing additional products to it, is really one big continuous experiment in customer discovery.

title: How To Handle Advisory Shares (5 minute read)
content: An X thread exploring who should get advisory shares, how much they should get, why you might give advisory shares, and potential pitfalls.

title: Intently (Product)
content: Turn LinkedIn actions into sales opportunities by validating your ideal customer profile, finding look-alike leads for your pipeline, and tracking key accounts with behavioral data.

title: Expert Remote (Product)
content: Hire top-quality developers vetted for technical and communication skills.

title: Buska (Product)
content: Find out who’s talking about your company on the internet and social networks.

title: Your product is boring (4 minute read)
content: “Visual differentiation” - you’ve achieved it when a customer sees your product in the first 30 seconds, it’s crystal clear to them what makes you different from everything else they have ever seen.

title: Strong opinions weakly held (4 minute read)
content: “Strong opinions, weakly held” is a mantra used by Marc Andreesen. It’s a technique for decision-making under imperfect information. It’s about committing to a decision, moving fast and learning quickly, and then being comfortable pivoting when new information surfaces.

title: Lessons from bootstrapped companies founded by software engineers (26 minute read)
content: Five things that worked consistently for five bootstrapped founders: do things better than anyone else, create a “wow” experience, keep it simple, focus, and ship.

title: SaaS Competitive Advantage Through Elegant LLM Feedback Mechanisms (2 minute read)
content: While Google may be behind a bit in the AI game, they are leaning hard into their advantage of all-the-eyeballs-in-the-universe. The feedback loop on making sure results are positive is tight and depending on how they utilize it, could be a differentiator. Don’t count the GOOG out just yet.

title: Global Venture Funding In Q3 2023 Falls Again (4 minute read)
content: A great recap of Q3 funding across a variety of sectors. The short version: things are down except for the hot spaces and no end in sight for the IPO market slump.

title: The Hyper-Personalization of Everything (4 minute read)
content: A detailed take on how AI is going to impact the digital world as it relates to the individual consumer. Just as in media, hyper personalization makes it tough to build (or maintain) a juggernaut but also opens up so many opportunities for niche brands that can find their users.

title: It’s Time to Raise Your Debt Facility: Execution Tactics for Founders (8 minute read)
content: This article is a deep dive into funding options outside of equity. It is the first part of a multi-part series that covers debt options for startups. It is a great primer for those new to (or revisiting) the topic.

title: HubSpot Marketing vs. Klaviyo: Two Titans, Two Paths (2 minute read)
content: With so much of their data out in the open as public companies, it’s hard not to compare and contrast these two behemoths. One is focused on e-commerce, while the other takes a broader approach. They are both growing at crazy rates.

title: The Thin Line Between Bold and Reckless (4 minute read)
content: This article explores the Vanderbilt of yesteryear and asks whether we could possibly be as reckless again today. History always repeats itself and looking at it, especially with a lens on the current technology cycle, always yields helpful insights.

title: DataLens (GitHub Repo)
content: A modern business intelligence and data visualization system.

title: AI SEO My Site (Product)
content: Determine whether your website is searchable and rankable by AI-driven search engines and discover ways to enhance its visibility.

title: Nureply (Product)
content: Send AI-powered cold emails with unlimited automations.

title: Wheels Of Justice Slow To Accept Legal Tech As Funding Falls (4 minute read)
content: Even with the onslaught of AI company funding in the last year, legal tech has slowed significantly. The view from the trenches is there is a lot of noise out there with new companies appearing regularly but not a lot of meat on the bones or sales on the books just yet. It will be curious to see if this is a trend or just a blip.

title: Giving And Receiving Advice (10 minute read)
content: Giving and receiving advice is fraught with complexities due to varying motivations and the presence of ambivalence in advice-seekers. It's vital to navigate advice with discernment, acknowledging that valuable guidance can sometimes come from unexpected sources.

title: Open Source AI Business Models & Brand Moats (9 minute read)
content: We’ve seen how open source models can work and thrive over the last 25+ years and even as they mature and become more “closed” (*cough* Redhat *cough*), the model has lasting impacts. In the face of AI, not all playbooks are the same. This article provides a thoughtful and in-depth review of open source models and how AI will play in this.

title: Peter Thiel’s comments on Europe (2 minute read)
content: Of the seventeen $100bn corporations founded since 1990, eleven were in the U.S. and six in China. Is Europe priming itself for future success? It has the highest density of AI talent, the highest share of cited research publications, and a large student demographic studying computer science and engineering.

title: How to lose at Generative AI (4 minute read)
content: Great read on the tricky parts of creating value around generative AI for startups. While the incumbents are favored, finding your path and creating real value early is where startups can have a fighting chance.

title: 3D As The New Modality (2 minute read)
content: The realm of 3D computing is emerging, with advancements in capturing, rendering, and displaying 3D content on various devices. While companies like Apple and Meta are pioneering this shift, the transition from 2D to 3D presents both opportunities for new immersive experiences and challenges in ensuring consumer adoption.

title: 8 ways SaaS companies can use AI to get ahead (12 minute read)
content: From task automation to writing code, AI is adding leverage to how we analyze customer data and build products. The key takeaway here is that AI is enabling people to do a lot more, and if you’re not using it, you’re likely going to get outpaced by the competition.

title: My app stack: Frank Dale, SVP of Product at SalesLoft (2 minute read)
content: Frank Dale leads the Product Management team at SalesLoft. In this article, Dale breaks down the apps he can’t live without, including ProductBoard, Figma, Jira, Mixpanel, Pendo, and Looker.

title: YC’s Group Partners share advice on actually getting things done (16 minute video)
content: Chasing productivity can sometimes lead us down the wrong path. We end up doing work and optimizing things for the sake of it, rather than focusing on those few impactful things that really matter. Having the mindfulness to be able to identify the real work is the main battle.

title: Chatcare (Product)
content: Reduce your customer support efforts by 60%.

title: Hell’s Pitching (Product)
content: Pitch your startup idea and get roasted.

title: Stock Based Comp, for Dummies (4 minute read)
content: We all think we know how stock based comp (SBC) works, but it never hurts to get a refresher on its impact on the bottom line. A quick read about the impact of SBC using Expensify as an example.

title: The value of Customer Success (4 minute read)
content: Startups seem to be introducing Customer Success teams earlier in their journey. What used to be a post-Series A thing is now being introduced alongside your early paying customers. There’s often confusion across the organization as to what they really do. Are they a cost or profit center? Here’s how you can help ensure every department knows the value of Customer Success.

title: Nice teams finish last (2 minute read)
content: The bigger the mistake, the more clear you need to be with someone that they made it. Trying to be nice often involves sugar coating failure and this means you’re being unclear on the cause of the problem. Failure to tell people about their mistakes means you’re robbing them of learning.

title: An alternative way to think about growth (2 minute read)
content: Up and to the right, right? Hear me out, down and to the left is the way. Say you want to grow 10x in three years, instead of thinking about the present day and how you’ll get to that goal, start with the goal and work backwards. This acts as a forcing function to shift your mindset away from the incremental and to the expansive.

title: VC returns are at a 10+ year low (1 minute read)
content: We can’t say we’re surprised. Down rounds, inertia in the IPO market, and climbing rates of administrations were always going to impact VC returns. The second order impact of this is that LPs are likely going to be a little hesitant giving GPs fresh capital, which impacts the amount of funding available for startups.

title: M&A makes a strong comeback in the DACH region (3 minute read)
content: The absence of growth funding in the DACH region has been replaced with healthy M&A. The number of M&A transactions in the region has increased from 153 in H1 2022 to 235 in H1 2023, a 54% increase. Last month LeanIX was acquired for a reported €1.2bn by software giant SAP in one of Germany’s biggest ever tech acquisitions.

title: The true cost of compute (15 minute podcast)
content: In this short podcast, a16z unpacks the relationship between compute, capital, and technology. It explores the cost of training a model for startups looking to build their own.

title: Selling in stealth, category creation and expansion (18 minute read)
content: Ryan Lieber was the 40th hire at Snowflake back in 2014 when it was still in stealth. Starting as an SDR, he’s since worked on country expansion and program management. This piece explores the challenges of building a category-creating business and a few lessons learned selling along the way: the optimal SDR:AE ratio, pipeline health checks, and involving engineers in sales calls.

title: Tips for gathering product feedback (4 minute read)
content: Customers don’t really know what they want. Very few of them are able to envision and articulate new product ideas. Instead of asking them what they want, ask them more about their problems. The solution will start to become more apparent.

title: 11 Years Of SaaS Product Strategy (7 minute read)
content: Reflections on Tanda’s transition into a multi-product company, with key takeaways including the value of diversifying products, adjusting ineffective features, and prioritizing customer-driven demand.

title: AppManager (Product)
content: An AI IT agent for startups.

title: Puzzle (Product)
content: Effortless revenue recognition for Stripe customers.

title: Bisko (Product)
content: Bisko collects, organizes, and analyzes data from multiple sources and creates customer profiles to inform marketing campaigns.

title: Going from developer to CEO (14 minute read)
content: You’re either a builder or a seller right? This is a rundown from an engineer who turned into a founder and then switched to the business side of the operation. The biggest takeaway is how the move meant they ended up juggling lots of work streams and had to get good at fast context switching.

title: The top metrics for usage-based SaaS (13 minute read)
content: Usage-based billing seems to be growing in popularity. How do you know if it’s working? Here are the 14 top metrics you should be keeping an eye on.

title: Who Can Commercialize New Technologies? (5 minute read)
content: Investors often prioritize easily identifiable metrics, such as founder pedigree, especially when dealing with novel technologies that are still emerging. However, as technologies mature, the focus on founder backgrounds might not necessarily yield the best innovative ventures. Instead, the fusion of top-tier research with creative product perspectives might be the key to pushing forward in industries like AI, biotech, robotics, and more.

title: Open banking endgame (13 minute read)
content: Free market open banking in America led to a lot of innovation and new products, but it’s creaking at the seams because of a price war, ongoing reliability challenges, and concerns over consumer data. Incoming regulation is set to establish some standards around the control consumers have over their data.

title: Atlassian Buys One-Time Unicorn Loom at Hefty Discount to 2021 Valuation (2 minute read)
content: You have likely already seen this but it is telling that Loom ended up selling for a 35% discount on its 2021 valuation and 4-5x the money in. This is likely a sign of the real state of the market around acquisitions. Still feels like a good outcome and fit for Loom.

title: LLMs For Dummies (12 minute read)
content: LLMs are all the rage these days, but do you really know how they work? This article provides a high-level overview of the plumbing behind LLMs and then looks at four frameworks for LLM applications that might emerge in the startup ecosystem.

title: Why you should fail 50% of your experiments (6 minute read)
content: Intuition uses historical patterns, and as the world moves faster and faster, experimentation is becoming more important. Failure in these experiments is really where we learn. As leaders, it’s on you to cultivate a culture of experimentation and reprogram your team to embrace failure.

title: Commercializing AI in Healthcare: The Enterprise Buyer Perspective (10 minute read)
content: No doubt AI will have a hand in healthcare - it's just a question of how and by how much. This step-by-step guide will be ridiculously helpful if you’re starting an AI-for-healthcare company.

title: Chief People Officer Pitfall for Later Stage CEOs (2 minute read)
content: Don’t just put HR under your CFO. As you scale, the leader handling the people side of things needs a seat and voice at the exec team table. Getting this right is so critical.

title: How to get press for your product (102 minute audio)
content: Jason Feifer, editor-in-chief of Entrepreneur Magazine, discusses the high-level steps of securing press coverage for your product. From winning over freelancers to finding and courting the right publications. This podcast also touches on when to hire a PR agency and when you might consider bringing it in-house.

title: Moonhub (Product)
content: Moonhub is your AI-powered recruiter built to save you hundreds of hours.

title: Blaze (Product)
content: Create better marketing content in half the time, all in your brand voice.

title: Building your personal braintrust (5 minute read)
content: Your braintrust is a group of 5-10 individuals that can keep you accountable and hold you to excellence. Pixar famously had an excellent trust that met regularly to cook up ideas and smoke out mediocrity. A few key features of the members of the group are that they’re unbiased, have diverse experiences, open to radical candor, and have a vested interest in your success.

title: The PLG trap (48 minute video)
content: Tomas Tunguz and Oliver Jay, the former CRO at Asana, dive into product-led growth. As your understanding of users’ needs gets more sophisticated, and your resources become greater, moving into a dual approach of PLG and sales-led growth optimizes opportunity. In this video, Tunguz and Jay discuss the signals to look out for that indicate you’re ready to make that jump.

title: In conversation with Vinod Khosla (35 minute video)
content: Vinod Khosla joins David Sacks, Chamath Palihapitiya, David Friedberg, and Jason Calacanis at the All-In Summit to discuss AI, the state of venture, and more. Khosla drops a number of VC truth bombs about the value of their support.

title: A breakdown of the returns to investors after the Loom acquisition (1 minute read)
content: Loom had a $1.53 billion valuation in May 2021, but is now being acquired by Atlassian for $975m. Is this a good outcome for investors? For most of them, yes. And it seems nobody lost money here.

title: The sequence of $1bn sectors by country (1 minute read)
content: Taken from 500 Global’s rise report, this thread breaks down the sequence of sectors that reach $1bn of aggregated tech company value per country. Ecommerce and fintech top the leaderboard as the most common sectors to reach $1bn first.

title: How Dropbox Is Tackling AI And Why It’s Glad It Ditched Its Offices (8 minute read)
content: A deep dive into how Dropbox is handling two of the biggest trends facing startups today: AI and remote work.

title: The reason CMOs fail (4 minute read)
content: Firstly, if you’re at the earlier stages, you likely don’t even need to hire one. Stick with a VP of Marketing or Growth. But when you do, the biggest cause of CMO failure is butting heads with the CEO on marketing strategy. CEO founders often know their market better than anyone, and in the process, have become great marketers. CMOs, work with your CEO to co-own the strategy.

title: Building beautiful products with Stripe’s Head of Design (1 hour 34 minute podcast)
content: Katie Dill is the Head of Design at Stripe. She was previously the Head of Experience Design at Airbnb and Head of Design at Lyft. In this podcast, Dill covers the elements of great design, what to look for when hiring a designer, and various lessons learned on leadership and scaling organizations.

title: Use inversion for better decision-making (2 minute read)
content: It’s often easier to avoid making stupid decisions than it is to make excellent ones. Inversion thinking is a mental model that encourages you to invert problems and define what will lead to guaranteed failure. Now you have your guardrails and know what to avoid.

title: YC Application Optimizer (Product)
content: Boost your YC chances with an AI trained on funded applications.

title: Nudge (Product)
content: In-app experiences to activate, retain, and understand users.

title: Skylead (Product)
content: Close 3x more deals with LinkedIn and unlimited email outreach.

title: Making hard decisions and working through tough times (3 minute read)
content: a16z brought top executives together to talk about leadership. This link contains both written and recorded highlights from the sessions where they share their experiences launching products, navigating tough times, and generally running 21st-century software businesses.

title: The $100M valuation trap (2 minute read)
content: As founders, it’s easy to become engrossed in the thrill of securing funding, expanding the team, and growing the business. But if you raise north of a $100m valuation, you’re binding expectations to an outcome that’s really really hard to achieve. Knowing the ceiling you want to take it to and not over-raising is a useful strategy.

title: Making Hard Things Easy (15 minute read)
content: An excellent talk on why some things are hard to learn and how to make them easier.

title: The Techno-optimist manifesto (24 minute read)
content: This article provides a lens to look through that adds color to the challenges we face across the globe and why technology is paramount to our success as a species.

title: Working in Silicon Valley used to be fun. Now it's just another miserable corporate gig (8 minute read)
content: Employee satisfaction among tech workers has plummeted, falling in line with workers in finance and consulting. Reported ratings of work-life balance and compensation are down and many workers are struggling to find a new gig in tech.

title: What Loom and Klaviyo indicate about exit valuations (2 minute read)
content: This article compares last round valuations in private markets to exit values. In both cases, the exit values amounted to less than the last private round - discounts of 38% & 20%. Is this a solid representation of the state of play in tech?

title: A founder’s guide to 2024 planning (8 minute read)
content: Q4 has barely started, but it already feels like everyone is already talking about 2024. Where possible, take a short-term pragmatic approach to planning. Think about each quarter or half, rather than the full year, and build a bitesize modular strategy.

title: Some short actionable tacts on experimentation and PMF (11 minute read)
content: Finding product market fit isn’t just an early stage thing, it’s a constant evolution. For each new product you roll out, the PMF discovery process kicks off again. This post collates perspectives and insights from several podcasts and masterclass sessions covering experimentation and the path to PMF.

title: The complete guide to building effective roadmaps with examples and templates (20 minute read)
content: Whether it’s your product roadmap, marketing campaign, or the customer journey flow, having a chronological plan in place helps guide cross-functional teams to a collective focal point. Having an effective roadmap is your North Star and prevents teams from writing their own script.

title: House of Pitch (Product)
content: Send, receive, and filter cold pitches in seconds.

title: Story (Product)
content: Story helps build teams that can run on autopilot.

title: Avian (Product)
content: Connect your data sources and chat with data from over 20 platforms and share custom data chatbots with your team and clients.

title: Data is a people problem (4 minute read)
content: We often assume that data is factual, but data is often interpreted in different ways by teams depending on their incentives, and it means nothing unless it is used to inform good actions. Successful application of data requires that you align incentives across teams and set some frameworks in place that encourage teams to define and use the data in the same ways.

title: Lessons From Bootstrapped Companies (13 minute read)
content: With venture funding in decline, now’s a good time as any to put on your bootstrapping hat. Here are some lessons from five under-the-radar yet very successful bootstrapped companies, all founded by former software engineers.

title: Does your startup need a sales playbook or just a few plays? (5 minute read)
content: When you’re shifting from founder-led sales to team-led sales, you relinquish a bit of control and knowledge. The reaction is often to bottle this knowledge into a playbook and hand it off to the sales team as a guide to live by. The trap here is that most earlier stage startups don’t really know what works, and by building a playbook, you’re limiting the chances of discovering new tactics and thinking.

title: You don’t need a CRO (2 minute read)
content: Adding this as a headline because it seems a lot of startups are rushing to hire a Chief Revenue Officer at the moment. What changed? Do you really need someone in the C-suite, or simply a senior sales lead who can take some of the ownership off your shoulders?

title: 10 charts that capture how the world is changing (15 minute read)
content: These 10 charts cover a broad range of themes, from employee productivity to Gen Z behaviors. Each gives a visual window into how the world around us is changing.

title: CEOs Predict The End Of Remote Work (5 minute read)
content: This article looks at several tactics companies are using to make the transition back to office work more attractive for employees.

title: How to build a startup program (12 minute read)
content: Startups often sell to other startups. Building a program can act as a scaled on-ramp and acquisition strategy. There’s a lot to balance here, from setting up your website and application forms to building partnerships with accelerators and incubators. This guide breaks it down step-by-step.

title: Eight tips for scaling a product team without sacrificing quality (13 minute read)
content: As your product team grows, the range of opinions increases and culture changes. Your ability to refactor and align these differences will be the difference between success and failure. Defining swimlanes and having a culture of clear and open communication are table stakes.

title: Always Cheer (2 minute read)
content: Jason Fried drops some science on just being positive. In a world where it’s hard to avoid that person on X or Reddit who is complaining about a co-worker, wouldn’t it be great to lead with positivity? Just a friendly reminder.

title: Told (Product)
content: Collect user feedback with in-product surveys.

title: Stripe Embedded Checkout (Product)
content: Embed Stripe’s prebuilt payment form directly into your site.

title: ProductAI (Product)
content: Generate product photos with AI.

title: How Zapier grows: automating growth (40 minute read)
content: Lessons on scaling to $230M ARR, acquiring 3M users, and reaching a $5B valuation with just $1.3 million in funding. That’s wild! The lack of funding acted as a forcing function to build a really smart and capital-efficient company. This is a long deep-dive fit for a Sunday morning coffee.

title: Nothing matters (4 minute read)
content: This isn’t a post about nihilism. What it’s saying is that most things don’t matter. Stop stressing about all the undone tasks and simply focus your energy on the one or two things that really matter. For Netflix founder Marc Randolph, this was differentiation and customers.

title: 5 Interesting Learnings from Domo at $320,000,000 in ARR (4 minute read)
content: It’s always great to hear from people who are scaling what they might do if they had to do it over. Scale is so hard to reach and it feels like hindsight is always 20/20. Good read from the crew at SaaStr.

title: Highlights from the State of AI Report 2023 (7 minute read)
content: The State of AI Report analyzes the most interesting developments in AI. The full report is 161 pages long, so here’s the director's cut showing the highlights.

title: The convergence of data and software engineering in the age of AI (2 minute read)
content: AI needs data to work, meaning data functions are getting closer to the core of the product-building process and moving away from internal business intelligence.

title: How private companies can adapt their equity planning to today’s market (6 minute read)
content: The private market seems to be split into the haves and have-nots, those with PMF and stable income and those without. This report suggests that the bottom line is talent. A strong and committed workforce is the main driver of success in the current environment. Incentivize them accordingly with the right stock options. This article explores a few options.

title: What to do if your top sales people are leaving (3 minute read)
content: The main driver for their departure is likely ongoing change, and the best antidote is effective communication. Sellers don’t like having to work harder each year to stay in the same relative position.

title: Fundraising advice for fintech infra startups (6 minute read)
content: There’s a lot of generalist fundraising advice out there, but a lot of it doesn’t apply to fintech startups building B2B2X infrastructure. Here are some thoughts from an early-stage fintech investor on how you can differentiate yourself and raise successfully.

title: AdEditor (Product)
content: Ad creation made simple by using your existing assets.

title: Ween (Product)
content: An AI platform that turns qualitative data into actionable insights.

title: Helpix (Product)
content: Solve most customer questions on autopilot.

title: Five Areas of AI Opportunity According to Snowflake’s Ahmad Khan (3 minute read)
content: The dust is settling now that the AI hype has started to subside. Digging in, where are the real opportunities in AI?

title: Metrics That Cannot Even Be Measured In Retrospect (9 minute read)
content: Some of the most important metrics are impossible to measure even after the fact. Staying clear of these metrics could be key to your success.

title: How leaders engage IQ and EQ (2 minute read)
content: It’s not about having one or the other - leaders need to have both and know when to deploy them. High EQ leaders are empathetic and good at rallying people together for a common cause. High IQ leaders are analytical and strategic. To be the best, you need a bit of both.

title: You can learn AI Later (2 minute read)
content: Everything with AI feels like when the web or mobile hit. “Learn HTML fast before you’re left behind!” “Does your company have an app strategy?!” The same is true with AI - we’re still in the noisy phase.

title: A SaaS metric for overall efficiency (6 minute read)
content: The Magic Number bundles together everything that goes into total Annual Recurring Revenue– including new users, expansion, churn, and account shrinkage–to give you an assessment of the overall efficiency of your annual recurring revenue. This post breaks down how to calculate it.

title: The 9 worst sales mistakes founders should avoid (14 minute read)
content: These suggestions are for all stages of startups, but more specifically for those in the early stages.

title: When to say no to custom feature requests from users (2 minute read)
content: If the potential deal is meaningful in the early days and the feature is already on your long-term roadmap and of use to other users now or in the future, seriously consider building that customer feature to win the logo.

title: A step-by-step guide to crafting a sales pitch that wins (90 minute podcast)
content: Good positioning is everything. Pitching your product is an articulation of how you’ve positioned it amongst competition within the market and aligned with the value the usage of your product would create for the potential user. This article offers tactical advice on creating a pitch, articulating value, and handling objections.

title: Dashboads (Product)
content: Instantly turn spreadsheets into dashboards and auto-distribute up-to-date reports.

title: Selzy (Product)
content: An email marketing tool with 24/7 support.

title: Gloww (Product)
content: Bring your meetings to life.

title: A business state of mind with John and Patrick Collison (78 minute podcast)
content: Stripe's co-founders, Patrick and John Collison, speak about how they organize engineering teams to ensure they work effectively.

title: How to develop your leadership style (18 minute read)
content: Micromanagement gets such a bad wrap. However, it’s sometimes needed. This article covers three primary styles of leadership and when to deploy them. Leading with policy, leading from consensus, and leading with conviction.

title: Parallel Bets, Microsoft, and AI Strategies (31 minute read)
content: Microsoft has survived several platform-level changes and come out on top. This article looks at the bets that the company has made throughout the last few decades. It covers how the company dealt with the transition from DOS to a GUI-based OS, the introduction of the internet and smartphones, and now, the development of generative AI. Microsoft's parallel betting strategy has led to growth in new adjacent markets, leaving the company better off. However, its strategy contained many uncertainties and might not be suitable for many companies.

title: Andreessen Horowitz May Be Optimistic About Tech, But It’s Still Slowing Its Deal Pace (4 minute read)
content: Even with “Software Is Eating The World” and the “The Techno-Optimist Manifesto”, a16z has definitely pulled back in 2023. Here it is by the numbers.

title: The resale revolution (10 minute read)
content: The average American woman owns 103 pieces of clothing. Globally, consumers acquire 80 billion new items annually—a figure that’s up 400% from 20 years ago. And we only use 20% of our clothes. Wild statistics, so what’s the opportunity for startups in this market?

title: What AI means for your product strategy (83 minute podcast)
content: Paul Adam, a long-term CP at Intercom, discusses the ways AI is going to impact the world (and your tech stack). There’s quite a bit of fear-setting in this conversation, so if this doesn’t inspire you to look into how you should be using AI, I don’t know what will.

title: 5 Interesting learnings from Freshworks at $600m in ARR (2 minute read)
content: The theme across these lessons is simply that Freshworks seems to be crossing the chasm into enterprise successfully. As it does so, it’s ramping up its product-led growth motion to ensure it’s still winning SMBs whilst its sales focus is diverted to the larger users.

title: How to tell if your VP is too hard to work with (2 minute read)
content: Groupthink can stifle innovation in companies. Opinionated VPs are great - you want there to be a degree of friction. However, as a general rule, if a VP is taking up more than two hours of your time per week, perhaps you need to dig into what’s going wrong.

title: Where are the opportunities for new startups in generative AI (3 minute read)
content: A solid breakdown of the categories of opportunities for generative AI startups in the coming years. Lots of great links to other related reads that augment this post as well.

title: HelpBar (Product)
content: In-app universal search, navigation, and AI-answers for SaaS.

title: ResolveAI (Product)
content: Resolve 50% of your support tickets instantly.

title: Tabular (Product)
content: Create responsive on-brand emails intuitively.

title: A crash course in M&A (21 minute read)
content: Exactly what it says on the tin. This long read dives into the basics of M&A and how they impact the market we like to play in. The reasons behind why mergers and acquisitions happen might surprise you.

title: Hiring benchmarks pre-Series A (4 minute read)
content: Seedcamp, an early-stage VC in Europe, has mapped out the hiring decisions from 60 of their portfolio companies with less than 20 employees. There are not a lot of surprises here. Across most sectors, engineers comprise over 50% of the first 20 hires. Sales hire types depended on the sales motion being product-led or sales-led, and early marketing hires became more frequent if the startup was in a competitive space.

title: The big reset in Seed to Series A graduations (8 minute read)
content: Series A funds are sitting on more capital now than ever before, but the rates of startups receiving Series A funding are low. Series A fund sizes are huge, so the required exit potential of companies they fund needs to be even bigger. This means investors are being really particular about what they invest in – the bar has been raised.

title: Reflections on a movement with Eric Reis (134 minute podcast)
content: The Lean Startup approach has been a powerful framework for founders for over a decade. Build MVPs, test, experiment, and iterate. Moving fast has been a guiding mantra. How relevant is this methodology in 2023 and beyond? Eric Ries, the founder of the Lean Startup methodology, dives in.

title: AI’s role in running software companies (2 minute read)
content: From helping you to write code to checking the quality of that code and adding repeatability to your content generation, AI is going to impact how we think about leverage in the daily operations of our software companies. This article explores the common areas where you should be thinking about adding AI to your operations.

title: Venture dealmaking falls to its lowest level in 7 years (2 minute read)
content: Global deal count in Q3’23 slipped well below pre-pandemic averages to its lowest point since 2016. What does this mean for you? Nothing we haven’t heard before–funding is harder to get and VCs are making decisions more slowly, prepare accordingly.

title: 10+ actionable things you can do in the early days to scale faster (4 minute read)
content: Do things that don’t scale your time but do scale your understanding and revenue.

title: When to consider offering free-trials or freemium (2 minute read)
content: Thinking about a free trial or freemium offering? Here are some questions to ask yourself. It ultimately comes down to how easy your product is to use without any guidance and the value that the customer represents.

title: Dear SaaStr: What does a US-Based SaaS company Need to Know Before Expanding into Europe (3 minute read)
content: It’s always hard to know when to go into Europe but if you have a universally interesting product, get there sooner and put boots on the ground. Landing in London usually helps as you’re close to pretty much every major brand on the planet and in their timezone.

title: Spoke (Product)
content: A priority inbox for product teams that reduces information overload, prioritizes work, gives instant context, and augments core workflows using AI.

title: Layer (Product)
content: Layer cuts your research time by 40% with AI-powered summarization, information extraction, and more.

title: FlowRL (Product)
content: Realtime UI personalization, powered by AI.

title: Sifting through the noise: How AI will impact information overload (5 minute read)
content: No doubt as a founder, you consume a lot of content on a weekly basis. Articles, blog posts, tweets, this newsletter. With AI, the amount of user-generated content is going to increase exponentially. The systems you build to defend your attention will be more important than ever.

title: VCs Have A Bad Relationship With Trucks (3 minute read)
content: The implosion of Convoy was hard to miss last week but VCs have a long history of screwing it up when it comes to trucking. They forgot about the most important part about trucking: the driver. This is a great breakdown of the state-of-the-state and things to come.

title: Gas Gas Revolution (2 minute read)
content: The price of doing business on the blockchain is only getting cheaper and will continue to do so. Does that mean meaningful business can finally be done on these platforms? The outcome of this crypto craze will likely be a wildly boring and insanely huge blockchain business, but it’s still another 5-10 years out.

title: Lessons learned from a startup that didn’t make it (11 minute read)
content: An insightful read from a founder of a venture-backed B2B startup that shut down. The biggest takeaways include: You need to really nail your ICP and build vertical use cases if you’re playing a horizontal game, don’t underestimate incumbents, and be mindful of confirmation bias from the supporters around you.

title: Startup make-believe (8 minute read)
content: We put this in the highlight because it’s a needed reminder. As founders, we like to look at the competition or the best in class companies out there. Sometimes this can be useful, most of the time it’s not. You cannot copy Google. Its search business is so profitable that it can afford to do all those quirky things, your startup likely can’t. Focus on you.

title: The state of VC in 2023 (30 minute read)
content: Sam Lessin, a partner at Slow Ventures and former VP Product at Facebook, put out an 84-page slide deck recently that digs into the state of venture capital. It’s a long but very enjoyable read that gives a poignant view of the landscape.

title: Letters to a Young Investor with Reid Hoffman (4 minute read)
content: Asking the question of what advice you’d give a younger version of yourself is a super interesting exercise and this time done specifically with Reid Hoffman. Hint: he missed Stripe.

title: Examples that bring gross margin calculations to life (6 minute read)
content: You likely wave the figure around when talking to investors, but do you really understand what goes into calculating your gross margin? Here are some live examples to help bring it to life.

title: A simple framework for exponential growth (7 minute read)
content: A bundle of insights from Lavanya Shukla, VP of Growth at Weights & Biases, on how to build a user acquisition flywheel instead of a funnel.

title: Groupthink (Product)
content: Groupthink joins your meetings, creates agendas, takes notes, and then instantly shares the summary with everyone else.

title: Coveragely (Product)
content: Visualize your online PR and link coverage.

title: Salesforge (Product)
content: Personalize every single email at any scale and in any language.

title: What does technology-enabled public safety look like? (4 minute read)
content: a16z is calling this “The Superhero stack.” They dive into what role tech startups might play in changing how we think about public safety and security response.

title: Synchronizing asynchronous remote work (7 minute read)
content: In-office, hybrid, remote–whatever working model you choose, there’s always trade-offs. If you’re even partially remote, igniting a sense of personal responsibility with your employees is critical. They need to know what their company objectives are, why they were chosen, and exactly how their role and daily work relates back to them.

title: The Impact of Anti-trust on M&A in Startupland (2 minute read)
content: Given the high concentration of cash and equity tied up in the top companies and their inability to do anything with it because of antitrust concerns, it will definitely put a damper on the M&A market with no end in sight.

title: Pixel Perfect: How AI Unlocks Creativity (14 minute read)
content: Rex Woodbury breaks down how AI, creators, and scaled distribution tactics like virality and community-led growth are generating huge momentum across these vectors.

title: VCs no longer do DTC (2 minute read)
content: If you’re a consumer goods company trying to raise right now, it’s super hard. So far this year, U.S. investors put just over $130 million into companies at the intersection of e-commerce and consumer products. That’s a whopping 97% decline from the peak in 2021.

title: Unpacking Amazon’s unique ways of working (93 minute podcast)
content: This podcast is with Bill Carr, someone who played a pivotal role in shaping Amazon’s digital music and video strategy over the course of 15 years. There are a ton of excellent takeaways, but a highlight for me was how to actually follow the “disagree and commit” principle.

title: Are Bigger Teams Better? (4 minute read)
content: A quick read by Sean Byrnes about when to think about big vs. small teams. The short answer is that it depends, but he breaks it down in an easy-to-understand fashion.

title: Top 10 mistakes when hiring a VP of sales (6 minute read)
content: Cautionary tales and sage advice for founders hiring their sales leaders. It’s about understanding the career game they’re looking to play, testing their knowledge of your product, and seeing if they’re going to attract sales talent to your company.

title: A Minor ChatGPT update is a warning to founders: Big Tech can blow up your startup at any time (3 minute read)
content: We’ve already seen it with investors not willing to invest in companies that are just wrapping GPT but now it is even more clear. With the ability to query uploaded PDFs, a whole swath of startups just got wiped off the map.

title: Adsby (Product)
content: Generate keywords with AI in seconds.

title: Liveblocks Comments (Product)
content: Enable discussions in your product effortlessly.

title: LDRS (Product)
content: Open-source loading animations for your product.

title: The only thing your investors want (2 minute read)
content: Surprise surprise, it’s growth. Even if your investors are compassionate, empathetic, and understanding, they still expect you to grow fast.

title: What makes a great acquisition? (21 minute read)
content: Google has made over 250 acquisitions. Facebook, Amazon, and Apple have over 100 each. Getting M&A right has been the difference between reasonably successful companies, and hyper-successful ones. But M&A is really hard. This article unpacks some of the elements of great acquisitions in this long read. Most of the case studies are late-stage companies, but the principles remain true if you’re an earlier-stage company looking to acquire.

title: The Generational Business Trap (8 minute read)
content: This post explores the concept of "The Generational Business Trap." The discussion is around how companies, even successful ones, can fall into the trap of becoming a 'generational' business that fails to evolve with changing times and customer preferences. The key to longevity is continuously reinventing oneself, maintaining customer-centricity, and fostering an innovative culture. The post also provides examples and offers practical tips for avoiding this trap.

title: OpenAI Is A Lot More Vulnerable Than You Think (4 minute read)
content: On the heels of OpenAI releasing functionality that decimated half of the GPT-wrapper companies, here is a contrarian view of the blind spots and weaknesses of OpenAI as this market continues to evolve.

title: SaaS unicorns expanding their TAM through acquisitions (3 minute read)
content: Larger SaaS companies like HubSpot and Clari are making acquisitions to diversify their offerings during a period of low capital funding, increasing user expectations, and growing resentment for running operations on dozens of point solutions.

title: How to Prepare for an Upturn (5 minute read)
content: We’re almost 2 years into this “recession”, and at some point, we’re going to turn a corner. All of that belt-tightening and pain is going to switch and entrepreneurs need to be ready to make the switch to growth again. This is a great read on how to hopefully read the tea leaves and ride the next wave.

title: What US-based SaaS companies need to know before expanding into Europe? (2 minute read)
content: Here are 5 great things to think about before you start to look at Europe as a new revenue destination. Staying close to your customers and speaking their language (literally) help.

title: Unwinding B2B SaaS growth in the current market (6 minute read)
content: As interest rates rise and funding dries, boards and leadership everywhere are expecting their GTM teams to operate more efficiently. This article unpacks what this actually involves, from bringing your data and sales teams closer together to refining your ICP and target audience.

title: What does a good nurture email look like? (2 minute read)
content: Excellent tips on how to upgrade your email nurturing once a prospective customer lands on your website, reads content, or creates an account. Make it personal and optimize for the action you want, not click-throughs.

title: Orba (Product)
